scraped_content.processed_markdown:
Content Item 1 (website) - https://asana.com/
1. Company Basic Information
- Mission/vision: Help teams move work forward; position: enterprise-grade work management that scales across orgs. (Messaging: “Human + AI collaboration that delivers”.)
- Main products/services: Asana core Work Management platform, Asana AI (AI workflows), templates for use cases (campaign management, creative production, project intake, product launches, org/resource/goal planning, onboarding).
- Business model: SaaS subscription (free + paid tiers) with enterprise add‑ons and integrations; templates/resources and demo → Sales-led for Enterprise; self-serve for smaller customers.

2. Personnel Information
- No executive roster on homepage. Key decision owners implied: IT/Admins, Team Leads, Product/Marketing/Operations heads (product pages target these roles).

3. Business Information
- Partners/integrations: 300+ integrations including Microsoft Teams, Google Drive, Salesforce, Outlook, Slack, Zendesk, Tableau, Okta, ServiceNow, PagerDuty, Figma, Twilio, Vimeo.
- Market position/scale: Claims 85% of Fortune 100; positions as platform that supports any scale.
- Financial data: Not on marketing page.

4. Technology Direction
- Focus on AI-assisted work (Asana AI) to automate tasks and workflows with contextual business understanding.
- Emphasis on integrations and ecosystem connectivity (300+ connectors) and BI/reporting support (Tableau, PowerBI).

5. Pain Points and Challenges (inferred)
- Need to provide clarity and accountability across distributed teams.
- Customer demand for secure, scalable AI that respects enterprise controls.
- Integration/interoperability challenges across complex enterprise toolchains.

6. Business Needs
- Drive adoption across enterprise stakeholders (doers + stakeholders).
- Scale AI safely while maintaining governance.
- Improve time-to-value with templates and prebuilt workflows.

7. Development Changes
- Product focus shifting toward AI-enabled workflows and end-to-end work management.
- Marketing emphasizes enterprise credibility and scale.

8. Policy Impact
- Homepage signals enterprise compliance is important (implied by targeting Fortune 100); specifics not provided here.

9. Competitive Landscape
- Positioning: enterprise-grade, AI-enabled work platform with broad integrations. (Competitors not listed on page.)

10. Success Cases
- Customers highlighted: Amazon, Accenture, Johnson & Johnson, Dell, Merck; case snippets: Danone, Kendo, Spotify, Gannett — focus on time savings, repeatability, campaign scale, centralized ecosystem.

11. Budget and Procurement
- Implied procurement: free trial → demo → contact sales for enterprise; Enterprise add-ons suggest multi-line-item purchasing and account management.

12. Digital Transformation
- Asana marketed as a platform for digitalizing workflows (campaigns, launches, resource & org planning) and centralizing work.

13. Industry Regulation
- Not detailed on homepage.

14. Market Opportunities
- Cross-sell into use-case verticals (marketing, IT, product, HR); enterprise upsells through AI add-ons and integrations.

metadata.description: Asana’s latest features revolutionize the way your teams drive strategic alignment and build smart processes that scale., Asana’s latest features revolutionize the way your teams drive strategic alignment and build smart processes that scale.

scraped_content.processed_markdown:
Content Item 2 (news) - https://asana.com/whats-new
1. Company Basic Information
- Mission remains work management with AI emphasis; product news focuses on Summer 2025 release (AI workflows, permissions, BI integrations).

2. Personnel Information
- No executives named in release page.

3. Business Information
- Release highlights enterprise-scale launch — implies targeting large orgs; offers add-ons (Permissions Management, Compliance Management).

4. Technology Direction
- Heavy AI investments: prebuilt AI workflows, AI Studio/Asana AI, AI workflows tailored per team.
- Integrations/BI: enhanced PowerBI and Tableau connectors; Microsoft Copilot smart chat; improved API.

5. Pain Points and Challenges
- Customers need secure, governed AI at scale; need auditability and role-based controls.
- Need cross-app insights to spot blockers and improve reporting.

6. Business Needs
- Rapid deployment of AI workflows (time-to-value).
- Robust permissions and compliance tooling for enterprise adoption.
- Better executive reporting/export (PowerPoint dashboard exports).

7. Development Changes
- Product expansion: AI workflows gallery, commercialization of advanced permissions/compliance add-ons.

8. Policy Impact
- New add-ons (Compliance, Permissions) respond to regulatory/compliance demands; role-based access control signals enterprise control requirements.

9. Competitive Landscape
- Differentiation via secure, prebuilt AI workflows and enterprise permissions; competitive threat from other AI-enabled work tools.

10. Success Cases
- Not in this release summary; marketing webinar and release kit available for case use.

11. Budget and Procurement
- New paid add-ons and enhanced connectors imply modular purchasing; customers must evaluate add-on cost vs. value.

12. Digital Transformation
- Encourages replacing manual processes with AI workflows (campaigns, kanban, goal operations) — opportunity for process automation projects.

13. Industry Regulation
- Compliance Management add-on and audit trails address regulatory requirements for regulated industries.

14. Market Opportunities
- Selling AI governance and workflow automation into enterprises; upsell path via add‑ons and BI integrations; opportunity within orgs needing cross‑app reporting and secure AI.

Content Item 4 (news) - https://investors.asana.com/news
1. Company Basic Information
- Public company (ASAN); product + AI focus; investor communications highlight strategic moves and financial reporting cadence.

2. Personnel Information
- Recent executive moves: Dan Rogers named Chief Executive Officer (June 25, 2025); Arnab Bose appointed Chief Product Officer (Sept 9, 2025).
- Investor relations posts signal C-suite decision-making and contact point for enterprise sales/procurement.

3. Business Information
- Financials: regular quarterly results (Q1 FY2026, Q2 FY2026 referenced) — public filings available (no specific figures in summary).
- Strategic milestones: FedRAMP “In Process” designation; listing in AWS Marketplace AI Agents and Tools storefront.
- Market position: recognized in Forrester Wave and Gartner Magic Quadrant 2025.

4. Technology Direction
- Continued investment in AI (AI Teammates launch, AI agents).
- Focus on compliance and public sector readiness (FedRAMP), and distribution via AWS Marketplace.

5. Pain Points and Challenges
- Need to regain/maintain investor confidence (stock volatility reported elsewhere), manage scale and enterprise security, and expand revenue while controlling costs.

6. Business Needs
- Drive enterprise adoption (esp. regulated/public sector) through FedRAMP and marketplace listings.
- Monetize AI features and platform add-ons; demonstrate growth in revenue/ARR.

7. Development Changes
- Leadership changes (new CEO, new CPO) indicate strategic refocusing on product and growth.
- Product commercialization via marketplace channels and FedRAMP pursuit.

8. Policy Impact
- FedRAMP status will materially enable public sector procurement; signals investment in regulatory compliance.

9. Competitive Landscape
- Analyst recognition (Forrester, Gartner) used to support market leadership claims; competition from other collaborative work management and AI workflow vendors implied.

10. Success Cases
- Investor news often references product milestones and partnerships; specific customer outcomes not detailed here.

11. Budget and Procurement
- AWS Marketplace listing simplifies procurement for AWS-centric buyers; FedRAMP progress opens public-sector procurement paths.

12. Digital Transformation
- Strategic shift: productizing AI agents (AI Teammates) and platform integrations to accelerate customer digital transformation.

13. Industry Regulation
- FedRAMP “In Process” and emphasis on compliance add‑ons (Compliance Management) address industry/regulatory requirements for public sector and regulated industries (HIPAA, audit trails).

14. Market Opportunities
- Public sector (via FedRAMP), AWS customer base (via Marketplace), and enterprise customers looking for secure AI workflows represent key GTM opportunities.

Content Item 5 (news) - https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/ASAN/news
1. Company Basic Information
- Public company (ASAN) — market coverage focuses on stock performance and strategic product launches (AI Teammates).

2. Personnel Information
- Media mentions tied to product launches and partnerships; executive names not consistently listed here.

3. Business Information
- Market sentiment: volatility reported (shares plummet/soar across articles); analyst coverage on valuation and growth story; news mentions partnerships (Moveworks), AI Teammates launch.

4. Technology Direction
- Market narrative emphasizes AI launches (AI Teammates) and automation partnerships (Moveworks); investors watch AI roadmap closely.

5. Pain Points and Challenges
- Stock volatility and analyst skepticism about valuation and AI execution risk.
- Perception risk if Asana lags in AI adoption vs. competitors.

6. Business Needs
- Demonstrate monetization and sustainable growth from AI features.
- Clear messaging to investors about roadmap and margins.

7. Development Changes
- New product launches and partnerships flagged as changing investment story (AI Teammates, Moveworks).

8. Policy Impact
- Not directly covered here.

9. Competitive Landscape
- Articles compare Asana to Atlassian, Bill (Bill.com), SentinelOne, GitLab, Procore — investors benchmarking productivity/AI software peers.

10. Success Cases
- Media references to product launches and partnership-related potential; business outcomes not highlighted.

11. Budget and Procurement
- Investor/market articles don’t detail procurement; note that marketplace/partnerships can affect procurement accessibility.

12. Digital Transformation
- Investors treating AI capability as core to Asana’s digital transformation offering and future revenue potential.

13. Industry Regulation
- Not a focus of these news items.

14. Market Opportunities
- Positive investor reaction to partnerships and AI rollout; opportunities tied to demonstrating growth/ROI from AI.

**(Personal) Chart color update:** Charts now use an updated color palette to improve visual consistency.

**(Starter) Enhanced password requirements and admin controls:** All users must create passwords of at least eight characters and cannot use passwords known to be compromised. Admins can raise the minimum password length for their domain up to 20 characters.

**(Starter) Proactive rule suggestions:** Get tailored automation recommendations in your projects, including AI-powered rules that can automate entire processes.

**(Starter) LLM auto-names rules**: When a new rule is created, an LLM will automatically generate a rule name for you instead of being based off of the rule trigger.

**(Starter) Reference custom fields:** Attach tasks, projects, portfolios, and goals as field values on tasks, projects, and portfolios to make relationships visible and ready for automation and reporting.

**(Starter) Relative date triggers now work on subtasks:** Apply time‑based triggers to tasks and subtasks, with support for date custom fields, so your automations can handle more of your workflow.

**(Starter) Script rule ownership and editing:** Project editors can view script rule details, claim ownership, and update scripts so workflows continue when the original owner changes.

**(Starter) Rule ownership transfer:** Transfer ownership of rules to another user to keep workflows running when roles change and ensure notifications go to the right person.

**(Advanced) Goals saved views and grid view:** Create personal saved views for goals, and now work with goals in a grid layout similar to projects and portfolios.

**(Advanced) Workload color picker**: You can now set the icon and color of a workload in the workload action menu.

**(Advanced) Time entry editing permissions:** Users can no longer edit other user’s time entries, helping maintain accurate records and support approvals.

- **(Personal) Less feedback in Slack:** Action confirmations now appear as threaded replies instead of top‑level posts, reducing channel noise with the Slack+Asana integration.
- **(Personal) Mobile push notifications sync across devices:** You won’t receive a mobile push if you’ve already archived the same notification in your Asana inbox on web.
- **(Personal) Guest authentication with magic links**: Guests can sign in with one-time, time‑bound magic links that meet FedRAMP/NIST identity standards; events are tracked in audit logs and honor domain session policies.
- **(Personal) Multi-filter and multi-sort:** Apply multiple filters and multiple sorts in project views on Android, matching iOS.
- **(Personal) Hide all images on Board view:** Use the view options toggle to turn off cover images across your board so you can scan tasks more easily.
- **(Personal)** **Comment drafts sync on Android:** Start a comment on web or iOS and pick it up on Android, and vice versa. This initial release supports text-only drafts.
- **(Personal) Team pages**: Edit the name and description of curated items without deleting and recreating them.
- **(Personal) View AI activities and reasoning in task details and Inbox on iOS** and Android, matching the web experience. This helps you understand what an AI workflow did and why.
- **(Starter)** Request access and responses are now available for goals, dashboards, workload, capacity plans, and bundles. On mobile, approvers can now approve or reject these requests in‑app.
- **(Starter) AI Studio Plus:** Purchase AI Studio Plus directly in the admin console to add AI credits beyond Basic limits. Learn more in AI Studio Plus.
- **(Starter) AI Studio attachments:** Asana AI can now read attachments from Dropbox and Box.
- **(Starter) Data retrieval upgrades:** AI Studio can now access more of the Work Graph, making it easier for smart workflows to find the right context.
- **(Starter) Smart chat improvements**: Smart chat now tailors answers to your role, function, and use case to deliver more relevant responses. It has a better understanding of sections and custom fields when your question is scoped to a project or My tasks, improving answer relevance.
- **(Advanced) Goals editor and viewer access levels**: Share goals more broadly while controlling who can make changes with new editor and viewer roles.
- **(Advanced) Zoom transcript summary automation:** Zoom meeting transcripts can now trigger rules and AI Studio workflows to generate meeting summaries and create follow‑up tasks after recorded calls.
- **(Enterprise) Permissions Management and Compliance Management add-ons:** Purchase advanced permissions and compliance capabilities without a full Enterprise+ subscription.
- **(Enterprise) Seamless activation for view-only licenses**: Admins in Enterprise and Enterprise+ organizations can assign and manage view-only licenses directly in the admin console without assistance from Asana support.

**(Enterprise) Placeholders in capacity planning**: Plan work before assigning specific people by using role-based placeholders (like “Designer” or “Backend Engineer”) in capacity plans.

- **(Personal)** **Swimlanes on board view:** Organize tasks into horizontal rows by sections, assignees, or custom fields in board view.

- **(Personal)** **CSV Import improvements**: Get clearer row limit warnings, updated status messages, and email notifications when your CSV import completes or fails.

- **(Personal)** **Granular API scopes for existing apps**: Enable existing API applications to adopt granular permission scopes—including new webhook creation scopes—providing enhanced security and access controls without requiring app recreation.

- **(Personal)** **Task templates respect work schedule**: Choose whether task templates accommodate work schedules with a new toggle in task template settings, keeping due dates aligned with your team's working hours and preventing scheduling conflicts.

- **(Personal)** **Admin console dark mode**: Enjoy dark mode support in the admin console

- **(Personal) Improved color customization**: Use a refreshed palette that provides more depth and visual consistency across projects, teams, and your workspace.

- **(Personal) Quick find and Contextual search**: Navigate large projects effortlessly with Quick find to instantly filter tasks by name in your current view, plus Contextual search to quickly access global search filtered by your project. Available across projects and My tasks on list, board, Gantt, and calendar views.

- **(Starter)** **Create tasks with custom task types on mobile**: Create custom task types using your project's default custom task type (like "Bug" or "Ticket") directly from iOS and Android.

- **(Starter)** **NZD currency option for number custom fields**: Select New Zealand Dollar (NZD) as a currency format when creating number custom fields.

- **(Starter)** **Smart chat scroll behavior updates**: Experience improved navigation in smart chat with enhanced auto-scrolling that focuses on the latest responses and a new floating button to quickly jump to the bottom of conversation threads.

- **(Starter)** **Convert tasks to milestones with automation**: Use rules to automatically convert tasks into milestones.

- **(Starter)** **Create multiple dashboard tabs**: Organize different reporting views by adding multiple dashboard tabs to projects and My tasks, with the ability to duplicate tabs within projects.

- **(Starter)** **Words to workflows in AI Studio**: Create Smart workflows by simply describing what you want in plain language, and let AI automatically set up the appropriate triggers, conditions, and actions for you.

- **(Advanced)** **Amazon Q index integration**: Connect Asana AI to your organization's Amazon Q index to access information from third-party apps like Google Drive, SharePoint, Slack, Gmail, Outlook, and Salesforce.

- **(Advanced)** **Enhanced Power BI integration**: Access expanded data exports including portfolios, projects, tasks, subtasks, and custom fields with improved table organization and faster refresh rates.

- **(Advanced) Enhanced Tableau Connector:** Access comprehensive data export including portfolios, projects, tasks, subtasks, and custom fields with improved four-hour refresh frequency and optimized table structures for easier business intelligence analysis.

- ( **Advanced) Week numbers in workload and capacity planning**: See the week number displayed in workload and capacity planning views, which may be especially useful for EMEA teams who frequently reference work by week numbers.

- **(Enterprise) Private custom fields in rules and bundles**: Use private custom fields in your workflows and bundles without compromising data privacy.

- **(Enterprise) Portfolio dashboard exports to PowerPoint**: Create compelling executive summaries by exporting portfolio dashboards directly to PowerPoint.

- **(Enterprise+) IP allowlisting**: Restrict access to your Asana organization based on specific IP addresses to meet regulatory compliance requirements for users in regulated industries.

- **​​(Starter) Jira sync ownership transfer**: Enable workflow continuity by allowing project admins and editors to delete existing Jira syncs and set up new ones when the original sync owner leaves the organization.

- **(Advanced) Jira Software Cloud comment sync**: Automatically sync comments between Asana tasks and Jira issues to keep teams connected and collaborating..
- **(Advanced) Improved custom task type creation flow**: Improve workflow management with a redesigned experience to create custom task type, featuring an intuitive modal interface, simplified color options, and new progress icons.

- **(Starter) AI Studio Plus**: Level up productivity for individuals and small teams with a new monthly plan for building AI workflows to pass off busywork.

- **(Enterprise+) Activity based session expiry**: Strengthen your organization's security with configurable idle session timeout settings that automatically log out inactive users after a specified period

- **(Advanced) Rule execution history**: Track and analyze your workflow performance with detailed execution logs for rules, including AI Studio rules.

- **(Advanced) AI Studio robust error handling**: AI Studio now provides more descriptive errors and warnings as users create AI Studio rules.

metadata.title: Asana Release Notes
metadata.description: Stay up to date with Asana’s latest features, improvements, and bug fixes from the official release notes.

scraped_content.processed_markdown:
Content Item 6 (news) - https://help.asana.com/s/article/release-notes
1. Company Basic Information
- Asana operates a continuous release cadence; product categorized by persona (Personal/Starter/Advanced/Enterprise/Enterprise+) and use-case orientation.

2. Personnel Information
- Release notes are product team outputs; no exec names listed.

3. Business Information
- Product packaging evolution: legacy plans transitioned to Starter and Advanced; Enterprise add-ons (Permissions, Compliance) sold separately; AI Studio pricing/credits and AI Studio Plus options for purchase.

4. Technology Direction
- Feature highlights (2024–2025): AI Studio (no-code AI rules), Asana AI features (smart summaries, smart goals, smart editor, smart chat), Amazon Q index integration, enhanced PowerBI/Tableau connectors, granular API scopes, custom scripts (Node.js) in rules, IP allowlisting, FedRAMP-related anti-virus scanning.
- Emphasis on real‑time exports, data access for BI, robust automation, extensible APIs and admin controls.

5. Pain Points and Challenges
- Enterprises need fine-grained permissions, auditability, data residency, and security controls; scale challenges include rule execution history, performance of connectors/exports.

6. Business Needs
- Admin features for large orgs (role-based controls, view-only licenses, sandbox self-serve).
- Billing and packaging clarity (plan transitions) to avoid customer confusion.

7. Development Changes
- Regular rollout of features by persona tier; introduction of paid add-ons and per-workflow AI usage tracking; new Starter features to broaden SMB footprint.

8. Policy Impact
- Enhancements address compliance (audit trails, EKM, FedRAMP requirements) and local tax/VAT/billing changes across countries.

9. Competitive Landscape
- Feature velocity and enterprise-grade controls used to maintain differentiation; connectors to Jira, Salesforce strengthen interoperability vs competitors.

10. Success Cases
- Release notes reference pre-built workflow templates and smart workflow gallery as accelerators for adoption (implicitly used in customer case studies elsewhere).

11. Budget and Procurement
- In-product purchase options (AI Studio Plus in admin console), add-ons purchased separately → procurement must evaluate seat/license mix vs add‑on costs.

12. Digital Transformation
- Tools to migrate manual workflows to automated AI rules; richer BI exports to support strategic reporting/portfolio management.

13. Industry Regulation
- Multiple compliance features: HIPAA, EKM, IP allowlisting, data residency, audit logs — indicates regulatory requirement response.

14. Market Opportunities
- Selling AI Studio and prebuilt AI rules; cross-sell of enterprise security/compliance add-ons; enable public sector via FedRAMP/anti-virus scanning.

Content Item 7 (news) - http://status.asana.com/
1. Company Basic Information
- Operational status portal for Asana services (App, API, Mobile, Automations, Webhooks, Notifications) across regions (US, EU, Japan, Australia).

2. Personnel Information
- Not applicable (status site).

3. Business Information
- Uptime metrics shown; historical incidents logged; transparency intended for enterprise customers.

4. Technology Direction
- Reliance on cloud infrastructure (AWS referenced in incident post‑mortems); monitoring and incident response practices visible.

5. Pain Points and Challenges
- Outages and degraded performance (notable: Oct 20 AWS-related global outage; Oct 31 EU performance event); reliance on third-party infra (AWS DynamoDB) introduces resilience risk.

6. Business Needs
- Improve infrastructure resilience, multi-region redundancy, incident communication and SLAs to satisfy enterprise customers.

7. Development Changes
- Ongoing investments in monitoring and mitigation strategies; postmortems published.

8. Policy Impact
- Service reliability and incident transparency can affect contractual SLAs and procurement decisions for regulated customers.

9. Competitive Landscape
- Reliability is a differentiator — outages expose risk to customers considering alternatives.

10. Success Cases
- Not applicable; status site documents incident resolution and operational recovery.

11. Budget and Procurement
- Enterprises will evaluate SLA history and incident response when deciding procurement and risk mitigation (e.g., backup processes, failover).

12. Digital Transformation
- Customers integrating Asana into critical workflows require high availability — drives demand for enterprise+ features like IP allowlisting and sandbox environments.

13. Industry Regulation
- Downtime and incident management affect compliance (audit logs, continuity planning) for regulated customers.

14. Market Opportunities
- Selling resiliency guarantees (Enterprise+/add-ons), managed onboarding, and professional services to mitigate operational risk.

scraped_content.markdown:

# Circling Ourselves: The Story Behind Asana’s Rebrand

Micah Daigle

Micah Daigle

Follow

16 min read

·

Oct 1, 2015

44

Listen

Share

Press enter or click to view image in full size

On the surface, this is the story of how Asana went from a logo with three circles to a logo… with three circles. But like most things that seem simple at first blush, there’s a lot more to this story than meets the eye.

Our evolved logo — a symbol of collaboration and shared energy — is the cornerstone of our new brand identity: a total rethink of how we present ourselves to the world. But more than that, it’s the end result of a year-long labor of love. And we feel pretty damn good about it.

But this isn’t just a “woo-hoo, we did it!” post. This is a tale of how we got from Point A to Point B — a trail of breadcrumbs tracing our path, including lessons learned along the way and advice for other travelers.

It’s also about the keys to our success: **a constant circling back** to the core questions of who we are and what we stand for, and a commitment to **closing the circle** on each element of our brand as we moved forward.

I wish more posts like this existed before we began our process (there are plenty of agency case studies, but very few from the client side). So, if you’re considering updating your company’s brand or are just curious about how it works, we hope our story helps!

## Why did we embark on a rebrand?

Let me start by introducing you to Fred.

Fred is a really sweet guy. Smart, good-hearted, there when you need him. Exactly the kind of guy you’d go out of your way to introduce to friends.

But Fred… doesn’t make new friends easily.

The thing is, despite his kind soul, Fred gives off an awkward first impression. He’s been sporting the same worn-out suit every day for the past five years. He speaks earnestly, but in an overly-professional and impersonal tone. Fred’s hard to get to know.

So when his friends introduce him to other people, they whisper: **“Give the guy a chance; you’ll love him once you get to know him.”**

Until this week, that’s how many of us felt about our brand and our product.

Of course I’m biased, but I thought Asana was pretty awesome even before I worked here. I was one of thousands of customers who swore by it when working on big, collaborative projects. And I came to find out that the team is equally awesome: full of big hearts, sharp minds, and quirky personalities.

But just like Fred, **all of that character just wasn’t coming through in how we presented ourselves.**

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**The old Asana**

To begin with, our logo was uninspired: an “a” followed by a three-dots symbolizing… enumeration? List items? Alignment? (Nobody’s exactly sure.) Our color scheme was a drab blue and grey (self-deprecatingly referred to as “rainy day theme” ☔️). Our writing often lacked the humor and humility that were so abundant in our team. Even the images we featured of real Asana employees somehow managed to look like stock photos!

In an ocean of bland, blue-tinted enterprise software, we saw ourselves as a magical, multicolored narwhal — but if you looked at us from the outside, it’s understandable if all you saw was another fish. 🐟

### Digging Deep

About a year ago, we started the process of redesigning our product. We knew that many users found the interface cluttered and drab, so we set out to clean and brighten it up. But as we started to dig into the implications of a product redesign, we fell down a rabbit hole that led directly to our brand.

After all, it’s hard to create clear information hierarchy with only one font, so it was natural to start looking at new typography. Brightening the app meant creating a new color palette and illustration style, but that also meant finding a way to keep those consistent with the logo… or make a new logo.

We dug ever deeper. _If we’re brightening up our design, should we brighten up our writing too? How playful is too playful? How serious is too serious? Who are we trying to appeal to? Who are we trying to be?_ As we started to unearth all these questions, our design lead Amanda pulled together a meeting.

We weighed the pros and cons of opening pandora’s logo. We were stretched thin as it was, and a rebrand could be a timesuck that delays everything else. But if we were ever going to do it, now was the time. Our new product needed a strong foundation — but it was unclear whether we should patch up the one we had, or create a new one from scratch.

We decided to take the first, cautious step of assessing our current brand, and go from there. Thinking back on it, I don’t think any of us walked out of that meeting expecting that we’d ultimately make such a radical departure from our existing brand. But I’m glad we did.

In a year’s time, all those images above evolved to look like this:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**The new Asana**

The new Asana is clear, colorful, and quirky. It’s a place to focus on your work, while remembering that work doesn’t need to be boring. When you check off a task or ❤ a teammate’s comment, bursts of color illuminate the screen to celebrate your progress. If you’re lucky, you may even spot a wild unicorn wishing you a good day.

In other words: Goodbye rainy day. Hello rainbow. 🌈

## So, how did we get here?

### Step 1: Unearth the core of our brand

Let’s go back to Fred.

That simple metaphor — our brand as a person — became a core aspect of our thinking from early on. We frequently circled back to a simple question when we needed direction:

> **“If Asana were a person, what would they be like?”**

At the core, each person is a product of our biggest goals, our values, our personality, and our life story. When applied to an entire company, these are generally known as **Mission**, **Values**, **Attributes**, and **Narrative**.

Thankfully, Asana has long had a clearly-defined Mission: **Help humanity thrive by enabling all teams to work together effortlessly.**(Audacious, no?)And our Values were established by our founders from day one, leading to a culture based on transparency, mindfulness, and more.

But what about _personality_? Goals and values lie below the surface, but a persons’s personality is on display all the time, giving others a more direct impression of who they are.

A year earlier, our founders had sketched out our company’s personality in the form of twenty-two Brand Attributes. They were a helpful start, but far too many to remember. Our first task was to narrow them down to a more manageable number, with input from people across the company.

We put out a survey asking: **“If Asana were a person, how would you describe them?”** The response was kind of staggering; thousands of (impassioned, emphatic) words were submitted over just a few days.

So, a couple of us printed out excerpts and locked ourselves in a room until we could make sense of it all. We clustered them together, debated the nuances of each word, and proposed Eight Attributes to Rule Them All.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

After honing with the rest of the team, we narrowed them down to six:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

_Our first stab at Brand Attributes, which were refined later with the help of Moving Brands._

A week later, we unveiled the Attributes at a company-wide meeting and hung banners around the office. The response was immediately reassuring. We soon heard people from all across the company referring to the Attributes in conversation (“I like that this e-mail is really Empowering, but could it be more Playful?”). Some even wanted t-shirts with their favorite Attributes on them. It worked!

And we were convinced. There was energy around our brand like never before, and it was time to go all-in. But where would we find the time?

### Step 2: Bring in some help

Within minutes of meeting the folks at Moving Brands, we really liked them. They immediately understood the big problems we’re trying to solve, and saw how much we were falling short with our brand. We quickly signed a contract, and opened ourselves up to their process.

It began much like our own: drilling into the heart of who we are and what we believe in. They conducted dozens of interviews, led workshops, and ultimately did a much more thorough job of soul-searching than we had.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**Looking at other brands to find inspiration. —** Left to right: Aki Shelton of Moving Brands; Amanda Linden, Justin Rosenstein, Kenny Van Zant, and Emily Kramer of Asana.

> Despite covering a lot of the same ground, it wasn’t wasted work; their own process validated and refined things we were uncertain about, while ensuring that they grokked the nuances as they moved into the next stage.

Ultimately, our six attributes were narrowed down to four. Less to remember, without losing anything essential.

Next came the Brand Narrative, a story that explains why we do what we do. It touches on the range of emotions — from elation to frustration — that most of us feel in our work lives, and ends with a **short-form narrative** that serves as a North Star for our brand.

By the end of this process, we had some solid guideposts to circle back to when in need of guidance, making our judgements far less subjective. For example, when assessing a design or a piece of writing, we could ask: _“Does this feel Approachable?”_ or _“Does this convey ‘Do great things together’?”_

If the answer was no, we knew we still had work to do.

### Step 3: Develop a visual identity

It was time to start translating all this touchy-feely philosophy into design, and naturally, our logo was the place to start.

A great logo is like a magic satchel: a small, simple thing that can be endlessly filled with value, without ever losing its form.

That’s why the best logos are so damn simple. They don’t try to convey too much on their own — they leave room for all feelings people will accumulate about the brand over time. Apple’s apple, for instance, or Nike’s swoosh: the symbols alone represent knowledge and motion respectively, but the quickest glance conjures a hundred other concepts, from Macbooks to Michael Jordan.

In short, **the strength of the symbol is in its ability to trigger a complex network of ideas and feelings**, not in the complexity of the symbol itself.

And that’s why Moving Brands nailed it on the first shot.

After a couple weeks of mood-boarding and brainstorming with our team, they proposed three logo directions. These are the sketches from the first of those options:

Press enter or click to view image in full size

The pitch: The three dots in our logo used to be arranged in a line, but now they’re huddled close together, _collaborating_. It’s the most simplified symbol of teamwork possible — three forms working together to make something greater: an upward arrow, a therefore symbol, an abstract “A”.

Some of us loved it immediately, but others weren’t convinced. Was it _too_ simple? Could it ever be memorable and iconic? And most importantly, does it look too much like the Predator’s aiming death lasers of death?

Press enter or click to view image in full size

Press enter or click to view image in full size

The two other concepts they showed us had elements that were promising, but they didn’t feel as solid as the first one. We didn’t want to choose a direction too quickly, so we asked them to keep exploring and see if we can find some other compelling options.

### Step 4: Iterate, iterate, iterate

Over the next month or so, we looked at dozens of logo concepts. Among them, we landed on a few solid directions, which got fleshed out with examples of how the mark could be extended into a design system.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**Explorations:** Sketches of logotypes and a mark concept called “Bloom”

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**Flow:** This concept conveyed the state of flow your team can get into when using Asana. We didn’t choose it, but it later inspired our final color palette.

Despite some compelling concepts, we kept coming back to the three dots. Moving Brands had iterated on the mark, adding a glow to the center to signify shared energy. Once we saw it in context, we started visualizing just how versatile it could be.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**The Three Dots:** Application explorations

Eventually, it became clear that this was our mark. Asana’s co-founder Justin (who had grown to love it after expressing initial skepticism) said it best: **“When I see this on my phone’s homescreen, it’s obvious: that’s the teamwork app.”**

Moving Brands’ designer Michael worked with Vanessa from our team to hone every aspect of it, from the precise spacing of the circles to the exact letterforms of the wordmark. Eventually, after a long day of squinting at dozens of just-slightly-different-from-each-other logos, Amanda held up a freshly printed version and said what we were all dying to hear: “Ship it.”

Press enter or click to view image in full size

### Step 5: Create a system

Of course, a logo by itself doth not a brand make. Now that we had a shining symbol of collaboration, we needed a design system that we could wrap around it and unfurl across all of Asanaland.

Moving Brands developed a typography and color system, and to tie it all together, a “Daily Flow” motif based on colors of the sky. The idea was that as you moved through your day, Asana moved with you. The logo, as well as the background of the app, would change accordingly. And the marketing site would reflect this theme in both messaging and visual style.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**“Daily Flow” motif**

We initially liked the concept, but as we saw it in action, it just wasn’t feeling quite right. We weren’t sure why.

Meanwhile, we were starting to near the redesign launch date and we needed to lock in the brand ASAP. Moving Brands was willing to keep working with us to get it right, but we decided to bring the last leg of the race in-house, where we could move faster and try things out in real-time.

### Step 6: Refine the system

When you feel like you’re close but it’s just not working, sometimes you push the direction harder. We did that for awhile, really trying to make “Daily Flow” work. But when we took a step back, it just still felt wrong.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**Motif Explorations:**“Daily Flow” explorations in the product. Morning, afternoon, and dusk.

So it was time to circle back to where we started. The sky tones were pretty, and the concept was cool, but we asked ourselves: _Is this motif embodying our Attributes?_

It was Approachable enough, sure, but Quirky? Nope. Empowering? Not really. And the heavily saturated color was distracting from meaningful color in the product, leading to less clarity. So it wasn’t really Purposeful either. “Daily Flow” was a novel idea, but we realized it was ultimately leading us away from our core brand.

So, we needed a new visual motif — something to bring all the pieces together in a more purposeful way. After re-grounding in the goals we had for the product redesign, our ideation quickly coalesced around a concept we coined **Clarity & Energy.**

Here’s the idea: When we’re at work, we all want **clarity** on what it is we have to do, so Asana starts with a **clean, mostly white canvas** that puts your work front-and-center. But we also need **energy** to stay focused and driven toward results, so **bursts of vibrant color and animation** appear at key moments to celebrate your progress.

Within days, our team brought the concept to life. It started with Jess and Buzz tossing confetti 🎉 around, then getting inspired by the colorful circle patterns, and riffing on that for illustration and site design. Then, Vanessa was stripping color out of most of the product, leaving just a few bright splashes in key areas. Tyson and Marcos jumped into Origami/AfterEffects and started making icons and illustrations come to life.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**Explorations of “Clarity & Energy”:** A white canvas punctuated by color & motion.

Oh and, for the hell of it, Tyson made a magic moving rainbow thing that you can control with your fucking fingers in mid-air.

**Stop showing off, Tyson.**

This all started to feel really right. By using color and motion in small, concentrated doses, we allowed ourselves to be more playful in those moments than we would be if the product wasn’t so spartan by default. And this meant we could finally **_embrace the unicorn_.**

If you’re a hardcore Asana user, you might know what I’m talking about. Several years ago, during an Asana hackathon, some engineers thought it would be cute to write some code that beckons a unicorn to fly across your screen when tasks are completed.

Judging it was too quirky for most users, it was relegated to the “Hacks” section of Settings, waiting for unsuspecting explorers to stumble upon it. Among those who’ve found it, it’s gained a bit of a cult following.

Steph Fernandes on Twitter – Medium

### Steph Fernandes on Twitter

The unicorn hack makes @asana the crème de la crème of task managers

Jackie Yeary on Twitter – Medium

### Jackie Yeary on Twitter

Earning a rainbow unicorn from @asana is always the highlight of my work day.

Christine Cawthorne on Twitter – Medium

### Christine Cawthorne on Twitter

Added the celebration unicorn so when I tick off a task in @asana I feel extra awesome. Unicorns FTW!

So recently we ran a little experiment and turned unicorns on by default for a subset of users who create new workspaces. Despite skepticism from myself and others, the test was a success! **More people ended up using Asana and collaborating with their teammates if they saw a unicorn once in awhile.** While some were a little confused about what was happening, most were just pleasantly surprised and delighted.

Tim Adkins on Twitter – Medium

### Tim Adkins on Twitter

I just completed my first task using @asana and a unicorn followed by a rainbow flew across my screen proving my move from Trello worthwhile

Bringing this back to our brand: our new motif became an opportunity to infuse this principle into every aspect of Asana. When executed purposefully, quirky celebrations aren’t just a throwaway flourish: they actually help people to stay motivated and have fun, which leads to getting more results. Who knew unicorns could boost productivity?

### Step 7: Brand all the things

From early on, we were determined to comprehensively roll out this new brand. It wouldn’t do to just slap a new logo on the website and tweak the colors; if a rebrand is to be successful, it needs full commitment.

So, the past few months have seen Asana’s entire design team working tirelessly to apply the brand system to every facet of our company and products (and our engineers making them come to life). It’s been a ton of work with a lot of dependencies. Many things needed to be revisited again and again as elements of the brand evolved simultaneously. But it was completely worth it.

Throughout this process, it was invaluable to have Amanda shepherding the process, ensuring that the circle was closed on each revisited element so we could move forward. Equally important was documenting these decisions, so that we could roll out the brand onto other properties in parallel, like this technicolor unveil video created by Giant Ant.

At times it seemed like all the pieces would never quite come together. But we kept on pushing it until it did. And we couldn’t be more happy with the response.

Carrie Walters on Twitter – Medium

### Carrie Walters on Twitter

Now that's a brand refresh, @asana. #newAsana

Danielle K on Twitter – Medium

### Danielle K on Twitter

Loving the #newAsana, especially the @asana iOS app! Beautiful new logo & gorgeous UX! #productivity

Liam Dilley on Twitter – Medium

### Liam Dilley on Twitter

Help me I am being attacked by the new @asana logo! pic.twitter.com/wVqaKL9Kbi

## Advice for your branding process

Here are the biggest takeaways from our process:

**1\. Involve a diverse set of teammates in branding as early as possible**, so the whole company feels like the brand represents them. It’s worth it!

**2\. Get outside help when you need it.** Not only may consultants/agencies have branding expertise, they bring an untainted eye and fresh perspective.

**3\. Give yourself time to warm up to a concept**, especially if others on the team are drawn to it. It may grow on you.

**4\. Insist on more options if only one is working.** You won’t be sure of your pick unless you’re able to see it next to other solid options.

**5\. Trust your team’s gut.** If it isn’t working, take a step back and rethink it. Encourage experiments with confetti. 🎉 Rebrands are rare opportunities.

**6\. Circle back to the core identity often.** If you did that part right, it should give you constant guidance when you’re not sure where to go.

**7\. Close the circle as you move forward.** Be sure to have clear decision-makers who can solidify changes, and propagate them across the team.

**8\. Have fun!**

P.S. Asana’s design team is hiring in SF and NYC.

P.P.S. Fred has lots of friends now.

**_Author’s Note:_** _This rebrand wouldn’t have been possible without the hard work and contributions of dozens of people. Major props go to the entire Asana design team: Vanessa Koch, Jessica Strelioff, Amanda Buzard, Marcos Medina, Stephanie Hornung, Tyson Kallberg, Francine Lee, Paul Velleux, Jim Renaud, Greg Elzerman, Anna Hurley, and Amanda Linden. Invaluable input/guidance came from Justin Rosenstein, Dustin Moskovitz, Kenny Van Zant, Emily Kramer, and Emilie Cole. And of course the good folks at Moving Brands and Giant Ant._

Now check out the ten lessons Vanessa learned from our product redesign.

Content Item 10 (case_study) - https://medium.com/building-asana/circling-ourselves-the-story-behind-asana-s-rebrand-e8247516705a
1. Company Basic Information
- Mission explicitly stated: “Help humanity thrive by enabling all teams to work together effortlessly.” Product direction: focus on clarity, energy, and user experience.
- Business model: SaaS; emphasis on brand and product UX to drive adoption.

2. Personnel Information
- Individuals named in rebrand: Justin Rosenstein (co‑founder), Dustin Moskovitz (co‑founder), Amanda (design lead), Vanessa, Jess, Buzz, and other design/product contributors. Moving Brands (agency) involved.

3. Business Information
- Rebrand effort invested in UX and visual identity to improve trial-to-adoption conversion and signal differentiation in crowded enterprise market.

4. Technology Direction
- Product redesign aimed at clarity & energy: cleaner UI, celebration mechanics (unicorn), improved information hierarchy — all to increase user engagement and collaboration.

5. Pain Points and Challenges
- Prior brand/product perceived as bland, impersonal, and cluttered; the rebrand was to overcome poor first impressions and boost user adoption.

6. Business Needs
- Improve conversion and adoption by making product approachable, delightful and clearer to new users; align brand with product experience.

7. Development Changes
- Comprehensive rebrand and product redesign across web and app; systematized brand attributes and design system.

8. Policy Impact
- Not applicable.

9. Competitive Landscape
- Rebrand positioned to stand out from “bland enterprise software” — differentiation via personality, clarity, and delight.

10. Success Cases
- Internally presented as successful: increase in engagement when people encountered playful UI elements (unicorn experiment increased collaboration in test).

11. Budget and Procurement
- Rebranding not procurement-related; but marketing/UX investments support demand-generation.

12. Digital Transformation
- UX and product improvements intended to lower friction for teams migrating work onto Asana, aiding digital transformation.

13. Industry Regulation
- Not applicable.

14. Market Opportunities
- Stronger brand/UX improves appeal to SMBs and enterprise buyers who value ease-of-use; marketing collateral and design can accelerate expansion into new segments.

Summary — Sales & BD implications (cross-content synthesis)
- High-value targets: large enterprises, public sector (FedRAMP in process), regulated industries (HIPAA, EKM use cases). Opportunities to sell AI Studio, Compliance & Permissions add‑ons, BI connectors, and professional services.
- Buyer personas: CIO/CPO, Heads of Marketing/Operations/Product, IT Security/Admin, Program Managers/PMO.
- Key pain points to address in sales pitches: secure, auditable AI workflows; governance and role-based permissions; integration with existing toolchains (Salesforce, Jira, Slack, MS ecosystem); performance/resilience SLAs; measurable ROI (time/cost savings).
- Competitive differentiators: analyst leadership (Forrester/Gartner), broad integrations, prebuilt AI workflow gallery, enterprise controls, strong case-study ROI.
- Risks/objections to prepare for: infrastructure outages history, stock/financial scrutiny (investor coverage), pricing/plan transitions, AI governance concerns.
- Tactical plays: verticalized case studies and templates, pilot programs for AI workflows, FedRAMP/AWS Marketplace positioning for public sector procurement, offer professional services for large migrations and resiliency planning.
